title: Textures
info:
Textures is an experimental publication that transforms thirteen artworks into an exploration of material and detail. Each section is printed on a mix of coated papers, silver, milk, and ivory. 
The artworks are fragmented into sixteen zoomed-in pages, inviting nonlinear exploration—lingering on details, flipping between pages, and uncovering new compositions. By shifting focus from the whole artwork and for allowing the details and textures to shine, Textures challenges the viewer to engage with overlooked moments in the creative process. Namely zooming in.

title: Best Dutch Book Design Student Catalogue
info:
Design of the student catalogue of the best dutch book designs of 2021, designed with Patrick Hutchinson and Alice Vink, guided by Bart de Baets and commissioned by Esther Scholten. 
The design of the catalogue reflects the tactile and instinctive way the student jury interacted with over 300 books during the selection process. With limited time for deep reading, their focus shifted to the immediate qualities of each book—how it felt, opened, bent, or even smelled. 
Inspired by this exploration, the selection was scanned in different ways to highlight the materiality and movement of the books. The layout mirrors the jury’s dynamic engagement, creating a visual narrative that celebrates the physicality of the publications.
 The catalogue was printed in offset by Drukkerij Tielen
Photos taken by Jón Helgi Pálmason.

title: Reykjavik Dance Festival 20th anniversary zine
info:
The RDF Zine was a collaborative project worked alongside Reykjavik Dance Festival, Sóley Frostadóttir and Sigurður Atli Sigurðsson. The idea was to make a punk-like DIY zine consisting of 20 years of materials from the previous RDF through the years. The zine is printed in offset by Newspaper Club in Scotland.
Photos taken by Jón Helgi Pálmason.

title: Color Diary vol. 1
info: A collection of artworks, textures and prints, made into a zine and printed with RISO Comcolor.

title: KABK graduation project Intuition Intermission
info:
Intuition Intermission is a collaborative workshop that nurtures creativity and artistic drive. Participants contribute to a collective process of creating zines by filling in spreads using different prompts and visual cues. 
These prompts and cues are based on extensive research into the 70s and 80s art scenes in the Netherlands and Iceland, which Einar’s late father was a part of. Through this exploration, Einar uncovers his father's extensive body of work from his time at the Rijksakademie in Amsterdam and the works of his contemporaries. 
The workshop emphasises the joy of creation and the possibilities in today's society. Participants visualise various aspects of stories, prompts, sketches, and more from the archives surrounding Einar’s father. 
Throughout the graduation show the table will be adorned with spreads which end up in different zines, that participants embellish using the provided tools. This work goes beyond just a creative process—seeking to create a welcoming atmosphere for discovery, connection, and playfulness. 
 Photos taken by Roel Backaert.

title: Result of the graduation project Intuition Intermission
info:
The book features the results of the workshop during the KABK Graduation Show in the summer of 2023. The book is printed in RISO Comcolor, and the cover is screenprinted.
Photos taken by Jón Helgi Pálmason.

title: Tangi kindergarten logo
info: A logo made for a kindergarten called Tangi located in the Westfjords of Iceland. The flower represents the kids, the colours represent the surroundings, and the lettering being skewed represents the many sides of the everyday.

title: Woah! Relax there David Carson design
info: Collection of images from weathered, ripped or torn stickers and posters, alongside graphic events around a few locations.

title: Slétting / Traces of Herring
info:
Book design for the photographer Jón Helgi Pálmason about Sléttan, an old herring village in the north of Iceland, that has become quite desolate in the years of the herrings disappearance. 

The book is bound in a way that makes it readable in two ways, one with the images of the town now, and the other with found archival imagery and newspaper clippings, showcasing the inevitable downfall of the industry.
Photos taken by Jón Helgi Pálmason.

title: Janúarráðstefna Festu / January Conference of Festa
info:
Drawings for Festa Center for Sustainability, for their yearly January conference on sustainability. The main theme of the year 2024 was 'We write the history of mankind' and the subthemes were 'Courageous leaders' & 'Societal factors in sustainability'. The idea was to draw so called 'machines' that are run by humanity in order to save it. These machines don't make sense, per se, but the message is clear. 
Photos by Ernir Eyjólfsson.

title: Identity for ArtScience pre-grad show
info: Poster, exhibition handout & t-shirt design for the Graduates of ArtScience 2024

title: Organization and identity for Reykjavik Art Book Fair
info: Visual Identity and materials for Reykjavik Art Book Fair 2024, designed with Agnar Freyr Stefánsson and worked alongside the main organizers Edda Kristín Sigurjónsdóttir and Joe Keys

menuItem: Een Kerk, Een Vrouw, Een Kroeg
title: Een Kerk, Een Vrouw, Een Kroeg by Joep Blom
info: Design of the graduation project publication for Joep Blom for his graduation from St. Joost School of Art & Design in Breda, Netherlands.

title: Vitar
info: Modern usage of the term trivia dates to the 1960s, when college students introduced question-and-answer contests to their universities. A board game, Trivial Pursuit, was released in 1982 in the same vein as these contests. Since the beginning of its modern usage, trivia contests have been established at various academic levels as well as casual venues such as bars and restaurants.

title: Exhibition in Outvert Artspace, Iceland
info:
For a long time I have been collecting pictures of shapes that appear around me, shapes that I then arrange and work with in various ways. However, it wasn’t long ago that I discovered theories that cover this called GRAPHIC EVENTS (Graphic Events: A Realist Account of Graphic Design). 
Graphic Events is a term for designs that happen by accident, develop over time, or come together of things that don’t really belong together. A sticker on a lamppost that has been partially scratched away, a torn poster, weathered advertisements, fog damage on a window, a scratch on a container or a scribble on a wall.
These so-called events leave a trail of beautiful, unexpected forms that tend to be forgotten in everyday life, something we see, but pay no attention to. Some years ago, I started collecting pictures of such forms/events wherever I went, and it turned into a picture book. The shapes and forms in the collection often end up in prints one way or another.

Now they have become a series in the show “Another Þrykk Up My Sleeve” (þrykk being a word for printing in Icelandic). The shapes and forms are used and put together in a variety of ways – sometimes they dance together or entangle each other. 
Photos taken by Haukur Sigurðsson

title: Sóknaráætlun Vestfjarða 2025-2029
info: Illustrations and icons for the operations planning of Vestfjarðarstofa for the Westfjords of Iceland 2025-2029.

title: ... Constant Need for Sketching
info: A collaborative book made with Alessandro Lucarini. The book is an experiment in blending techniques and perspectives together, two designers/visual artists with quite a different tempo, learning from eachother in many ways. The book is printed with RISO Comcolor, RISO and screenprinted.
